content: Since the mid-1980s, Congress has passed legislation to support older youth in foster care through the Chafee Foster Care Independence Program (CFCIP), providing services like housing. States have developed independent living programs with funding from CFCIP and other sources to help youth attain self-sufficiency. Federal law also directs child welfare agencies to develop policies for older youth transitioning from care. Research has shown that compared to their peers, former foster youth face challenges in transitioning to adulthood, such as lower rates of higher education, poorer health, homelessness, and reliance on public supports. Despite services like written case plans, these youth struggle more in their early adult years. Research, policy makers, and child welfare advocates have brought attention to challenges faced by youth transitioning from care. Congress is focusing on ensuring youth have connections to caring adults and support after turning 18 to ease the transition to adulthood. Federal policy makers recognize that most youth are not ready to live independently at 18 and are interested in providing a safety net for state wards. Subsequently, the 113th Congress passed the Preventing Sex Trafficking and Strengthening Families Act. The Preventing Sex Trafficking and Strengthening Families Act (P.L. 113-183) was signed into law by President Obama on September 30, 2014. It aims to protect older youth in care, promote normalcy for children in foster care, and requires child welfare agencies to respond to victims of sex trafficking.
